translated: 2Here is the corrected and aligned text:ğŸ”½MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra, Scroll 75
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
Chapter 20, Section 2: On Non-arising, Part of the First Chapter
ÅšÄriputra!
The perfection of generosity is a dharma that has already arisen. I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of its inherent emptiness.
The perfections of morality, patience, vigor, concentration, and wisdom are dharmas that have already arisen. I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of their inherent emptiness.
ÅšÄriputra!
The four meditations are dharmas that have already arisen. I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of their inherent emptiness.
The four immeasurable [minds] and four formless concentrations are dharmas that have already arisen. I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of their inherent emptiness.
ÅšÄriputra!
The eight liberations are dharmas that have already arisen. I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of their inherent emptiness.
The eight liberations, nine successive concentrations, and ten universal bases are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The four establishments of mindfulness are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.

The four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The emptiness liberation gate is an already arisen dharma, and I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because it is empty of its own-nature.
The signless and wishless liberation gates are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The five eyes are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.
The six supernormal knowledges are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The ten powers of a Buddha are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.

The four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of a Buddha are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because they are empty of their own-nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Omniscience is an already arisen dharma, and I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because it is empty of its own-nature.
The cognition of the pattern of the path and the cognition of all aspects are already arisen dharmas, and I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The Dharma of non-forgetfulness is a produced dharma, I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
The nature of constant abiding is a produced dharma, I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
All dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways are produced dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
All samÄdhi gateways are produced dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Ordinary beings are produced dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
The dharmas of ordinary beings are produced dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
I do not wish to cause the arising of the already arisen stream-enterer.
Why is that?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
I do not wish to cause the arising of the already arisen stream-enterer's dharmas.
Why is that?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
I do not wish to cause the arising of the already arisen once-returner.
Why is that?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
I do not wish to cause the arising of the already arisen once-returner's dharmas.
Why is that?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
I do not wish to cause the arising of the already arisen non-returner.
Why is that?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
I do not wish to cause the arising of the already arisen non-returner's dharmas.
Why is that?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
I do not wish to cause the arising of the already arisen arhat.
Why is that?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
The dharmas of an arhat are already arisen dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
A pratyekabuddha is an already arisen dharma, I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
The dharmas of a pratyekabuddha are already arisen dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
A bodhisattva is an already arisen dharma, I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
The dharmas of a bodhisattva are already arisen dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
A TathÄgata is an already arisen dharma, I do not wish to cause it to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of inherent nature.
The dharmas of a TathÄgata are already arisen dharmas, I do not wish to cause them to arise.
Why is it so?
Because of the emptiness of intrinsic nature.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra asked SubhÅ«ti, saying:
Do you now wish to cause birth to be born, or do you wish to cause non-birth to be born?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
I do not wish to cause birth to be born, nor do I wish to cause non-birth to be born.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!

Birth and non-birth, these two dharmas are neither in union nor not in union, neither having form nor formless, neither visible nor invisible, neither impeded nor unimpeded, all having the same single mark, namely, the mark of absence.
ÅšÄriputra!
For this reason, I do not wish to cause birth to be born, nor do I wish to cause non-birth to be born.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra asked SubhÅ«ti, saying:
Virtuous one!
Do you, with regard to the spoken non-arising dharmas, delight in speaking of the mark of non-arising?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
I do not delight in expounding the characteristics of the unborn dharmas that I have spoken of.
Why is it so?

If the unborn dharmas, the characteristics of the unborn, and the delight in expounding them, all of these are neither corresponding nor non-corresponding, neither having form nor formless, neither visible nor invisible, neither obstructive nor non-obstructive, they are all of the same characteristic, namely, the characteristic of non-existence.
ÅšÄriputra said:
In the unborn dharmas, the word 'unborn' is also unborn, is it not?
SubhÅ«ti replied:ğŸ”½So it is!
So it is!
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
Form is unborn, and feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also unborn.
Why is it so?
Because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The eye sense base is unborn, and the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases are also unborn.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The form element does not arise, and the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma elements also do not arise.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The eye element does not arise, the form element, eye-consciousness element, eye contact, and the feelings that arise from eye contact as a condition also do not arise.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The ear element does not arise, the sound element, ear-consciousness element, ear contact, and the feelings that arise from ear contact as a condition also do not arise.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nose element does not arise, the smell element, nose-consciousness element, nose contact, and the feelings that arise from nose contact as a condition also do not arise.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The tongue element does not arise, and the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings that arise from tongue contact as a condition also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The body element does not arise, the touch element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings that arise from body contact as a condition also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The mind element does not arise, the dharma element, mind consciousness element, mind contact, and the feelings that arise from mind contact as a condition also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The earth element does not arise, and the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The noble truth of suffering does not arise, and the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path also do not arise.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!

Ignorance does not arise, and the formations, consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, and agitation also do not arise.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!

Inner emptiness does not arise, outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of non-dispersal, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of general characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of intrinsic nature of non-existence, and emptiness of the intrinsic nature of non-existence of intrinsic nature also do not arise.
Why is it so?
because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The perfection of generosity does not arise, and the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom also do not arise.
Why is this?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The four meditative states do not arise, and the four immeasurable [minds] and four formless concentrations also do not arise.
Why is this?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The eight liberations do not arise, and the eight superior [meditative] states, nine successive concentrations, and ten universal bases also do not arise.
Why is this?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!

The four establishments of mindfulness do not arise, and the four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, five powers, seven factors of enlightenment, and eightfold noble path also do not arise.
Why is this?
It is because they are all empty by nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The emptiness liberation door does not arise, and the signless and wishless liberation doors also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The five eyes are unborn, and the six supernormal powers are also unborn.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!

The ten powers of a buddha are unborn, and the four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and the eighteen distinctive qualities of a buddha are also unborn.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Omniscience is unborn, and the cognition of the attributes of the path and the cognition of all aspects are also unborn.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The dharma of non-forgetfulness is unborn, and the nature of constant relinquishment is also unborn.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The gateway of all dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s is unborn, and the gateway of all samÄdhis is also unborn.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Ordinary beings do not arise, and the dharmas of ordinary beings also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Stream-enterers do not arise, and the dharmas of stream-enterers also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Once-returners do not arise, and the dharmas of once-returners also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Non-returners do not arise, and the dharmas of non-returners also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Arhats do not arise, and the dharmas of arhats also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
Solitary realizers do not arise, and the dharmas of solitary realizers also do not arise.
Why is it so?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The non-arising of a bodhisattva and the non-arising of the Dharma of a bodhisattva are the same.
Why is this?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The non-arising of a TathÄgata and the non-arising of the Dharma of a TathÄgata are the same.
Why is this?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
The non-arising of bodily actions, verbal actions, and mental actions are the same.
Why is this?
It is because they are all empty of inherent nature.
ÅšÄriputra!
For this reason, the non-arising of dharmas and the non-arising of words are both without meaning.
ÅšÄriputra!
Because the spoken Dharma, the words that are spoken, the speaker, and the listener are all non-arising.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra said to SubhÅ«ti,
You are the foremost of those who expound the Dharma.
Why is this?
Because you are able to respond to any question without obstruction.
SubhÅ«ti replied,
The disciples of the Buddhas, who are unattached to all dharmas, are naturally able to answer any question that is asked, each and every one, with ease and fearlessness.
Why is this?
Because all dharmas are without support.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra asked SubhÅ«ti, saying:
How is it that all dharmas are utterly without support?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
ÅšÄriputra!
The intrinsic nature of form is empty, because it cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
The intrinsic nature of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The intrinsic nature of the eye sense base is empty, because it cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
The intrinsic nature of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the form realm is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
The nature of the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma realms is empty, because they cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the eye realm is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.

The nature of the form realm, eye consciousness realm, eye contact, and the feelings produced from eye contact as a condition are empty, because they cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the ear realm is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.

The nature of the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, ear contact, and the feelings produced from ear contact as a condition are empty, because they cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the nose realm is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.

the sphere of smell, the nose consciousness sphere, and nose contact, as well as the feelings produced from nose contact as a condition, are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or somewhere in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The sphere of the tongue is essentially empty, because it cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or somewhere in between;

the sphere of taste, the tongue consciousness sphere, and tongue contact, as well as the feelings produced from tongue contact as a condition, are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or somewhere in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The sphere of the body is essentially empty, because it cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or somewhere in between;

the sphere of touch, the body consciousness sphere, and body contact, as well as the feelings produced from body contact as a condition, are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or somewhere in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The sphere of the mind is essentially empty, because it cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or somewhere in between;

The realm of phenomena, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact, and the feelings produced with mental contact as a condition are inherently empty, because they cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The earth element is inherently empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between;
the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements are inherently empty, because they cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The noble truth of suffering is inherently empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between;
the noble truths of the arising, cessation, and path of suffering are inherently empty, because they cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
Ignorance is inherently empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between;

The essential emptiness of volitional formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, depression, and distress is because they cannot be found based on the internal, based on the external, or based on both.
ÅšÄriputra!
The essential emptiness of internal emptiness is because it cannot be found based on the internal, based on the external, or based on both;

the essential emptiness of external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of non-dispersal, emptiness of inherent existence, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of intrinsic nature of non-existence, and emptiness of the intrinsic nature of non-existence of intrinsic nature is because they cannot be found based on the internal, based on the external, or based on both.
ÅšÄriputra!
The essential emptiness of the perfection of generosity is because it cannot be found based on the internal, based on the external, or based on both;
The nature of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between the two.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the four meditations is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between the two;
The nature of the four immeasurable [minds] and four formless concentrations is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between the two.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the eight liberations is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between the two;
The nature of the eight superior [meditative] states, nine sequential attainments, and ten universal bases is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between the two.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the four establishments of mindfulness is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between the two;

the four right efforts, the four legs of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the eightfold noble path are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The emptiness gate of liberation is essentially empty, because it cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between;
the signless and wishless gates of liberation are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The five eyes are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between;
the six supernatural powers are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The ten powers of the Buddha are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between;

The four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended as based on the internal, based on the external, or based between the two.
ÅšÄriputra!
Omniscience is essentially empty, because it cannot be apprehended as based on the internal, based on the external, or based between the two;
The cognition of the path and the cognition of all aspects are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended as based on the internal, based on the external, or based between the two.
ÅšÄriputra!
The power of non-forgetting is essentially empty, because it cannot be apprehended as based on the internal, based on the external, or based between the two;
The nature of constant relinquishment is essentially empty, because it cannot be apprehended as based on the internal, based on the external, or based between the two.
ÅšÄriputra!
All dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended as based on the internal, based on the external, or based between the two;
All doors of samÄdhi are essentially empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of ordinary beings is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between;
the nature of the dharmas of ordinary beings is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of a stream-enterer is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between;
the nature of the dharmas of a stream-enterer is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of a once-returner is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between;
the nature of the dharmas of a once-returner is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of a non-returner is empty, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between;
The nature of the non-returner is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the arhat is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between;
The nature of the arhat's Dharma is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the pratyekabuddha is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between;
The nature of the pratyekabuddha's Dharma is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the bodhisattva is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between;
The nature of the bodhisattva's Dharma is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
The nature of the TathÄgata is empty, because it cannot be found either internally, externally, or in between;
The fundamental nature of the TathÄgata's teachings is emptiness, because they cannot be apprehended either internally, externally, or in between.
ÅšÄriputra!
For this reason, I say that all dharmas are utterly without support.
The Venerable SubhÅ«ti said to ÅšÄriputra:
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the six perfections, they should purify form, they should purify feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness;
they should purify the eye faculty, they should purify the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind faculties;
they should purify the form realm, they should purify the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma realms;
they should purify the eye element, they should purify the form element, the eye-consciousness element, and the eye contact and the feelings produced from eye contact;
they should purify the ear element, they should purify the sound element, the ear-consciousness element, and the ear contact and the feelings produced from ear contact;
One should purify the nose sense field, and one should purify the olfactory sense field, olfactory consciousness, olfactory contact, and the feelings produced from olfactory contact as a condition;
One should purify the tongue sense field, and one should purify the gustatory sense field, gustatory consciousness, gustatory contact, and the feelings produced from gustatory contact as a condition;
One should purify the body sense field, and one should purify the tactile sense field, tactile consciousness, tactile contact, and the feelings produced from tactile contact as a condition;
One should purify the mind sense field, and one should purify the dharma sense field, mental consciousness, mental contact, and the feelings produced from mental contact as a condition;
One should purify the earth element, and one should purify the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements;
One should purify the noble truth of suffering, and one should purify the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path of suffering;

One should purify ignorance, and one should purify the formative predispositions, consciousness, name and form, the six sense fields, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, and old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and mental anguish;

They should purify inner emptiness, and they should purify outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, the emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of non-dispersal, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of general characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature.
They should purify the perfection of giving, and they should purify the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom.
They should purify the four meditations, and they should purify the four immeasurable [minds] and the four formless concentrations.
They should purify the eight liberations, and they should purify the eight superior [meditations], the nine sequential concentrations, and the ten universal bases.

They should purify the four establishments of mindfulness, and they should purify the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the eightfold noble path.
they should purify the door of emptiness, the door of signlessness, and the door of wishlessness;
they should purify the five eyes, they should purify the six supernormal knowledges;

they should purify the ten powers of the Buddha, they should purify the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha;
they should purify the power of recollection without forgetting, they should purify the nature of always giving up;
they should purify all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways, they should purify all samÄdhi gateways;
they should purify omniscience, they should purify the cognition of the path, and the cognition of all aspects;
they should purify the path to enlightenment.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra asked SubhÅ«ti, saying:
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the six perfections, purify the path to enlightenment?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
ÅšÄriputra!
The six perfections each have two kinds: one is worldly, the other is supramundane.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the perfection of giving in the world?
SubhÅ«ti replied:

translated: If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva becomes a great donor, able to give to all Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, the poor, the sick, the destitute, travelers, and beggars, giving food to those who need food, drink to those who need drink, vehicles to those who need vehicles, clothing to those who need clothing, incense to those who need incense, flowers to those who need flowers, ornaments to those who need ornaments, houses to those who need houses, medicine to those who need medicine, illumination to those who need illumination, bedding to those who need bedding, and so forth, giving all the necessities of life to all according to their needs.

If someone comes to request a son, I will give them a son; if they request a daughter, I will give them a daughter; if they request a wife, I will give them a wife; if they request an official position, I will give them an official position; if they request a country, I will give them a country; if they request a king's position, I will give them a king's position; if they request a head, I will give them a head; if they request hands and feet, I will give them hands and feet; if they request limbs and joints, I will give them limbs and joints; if they request blood and flesh, I will give them blood and flesh; if they request bones and marrow, I will give them bones and marrow; if they request ears and nose, I will give them ears and nose; if they request servants, I will give them servants; if they request precious treasures, I will give them precious treasures; if they request living beings, I will give them living beings. In this way, I will give them everything they seek, both internal and external things.
Although I make these gifts, I have something to rely on, namely, I think like this:
'I give to them, they receive, I am the donor, I am not stingy, I follow the Buddha's teachings and can give up everything, I practice the perfection of generosity.'
When they practice giving, they use something to be attained as a skillful means, and together with all sentient beings, they dedicate it to supreme, perfect enlightenment.
They further think:
'I give this merit to all sentient beings, enabling them to attain happiness in this world and the next, and ultimately to realize nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
They are attached to the three wheels in practicing giving: first, the thought of self; second, the thought of others; third, the thought of giving.
Because they practice giving attached to these three wheels, it is called the perfection of giving in the world.
Why is this giving called worldly?
Because it is practiced together with the world, and does not transcend, move out of, or depart from worldly dharmas, this is called the perfection of giving in the world.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the perfection of giving that transcends the world?
SubhÅ«ti replied:

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when practicing giving, purifies the three spheres, first, not grasping at self as the giver, second, not grasping at others as the receiver, and third, not being attached to giving and the fruits of giving, this is called a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's practice of giving while purifying the three spheres.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, with great compassion as the foremost, cultivates the merit of giving and universally bestows it upon sentient beings, he does not obtain anything from sentient beings. Although he universally dedicates it to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi together with all sentient beings, he does not see even the slightest characteristic within it.
Because he practices giving without grasping at anything, it is called the perfection of giving that transcends the world.
Why is this giving called that which transcends the world?
Because it does not share the same practice as the world, because it is able to transcend and emerge from worldly dharmas, this is called the perfection of giving that transcends the world.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the perfection of pure precepts in the world?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, although upholding precepts, has something to rely on, thinking:
'I uphold pure precepts in order to benefit all sentient beings. I follow the Buddha's teachings and am able to be without transgression in pure morality. I practice the perfection of pure precepts.'
When they uphold precepts, using something to be attained as a skillful means, they share it with all sentient beings and dedicate it together towards unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
They further think:
'I give this merit to all sentient beings, enabling them to attain happiness in this world and the next, and ultimately realize nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.'
They attach to the three spheres and uphold precepts: first, the notion of self; second, the notion of others; third, the notion of precepts.
Because one upholds precepts while attached to these three wheels, it is called the perfection of pure precepts in the world.
Why is this pure precept called worldly?
Because it is practiced together with the world, and because it does not transcend, move, or emerge from worldly dharmas, it is called the perfection of pure precepts in the world.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the perfection of pure precepts that transcends the world?
SubhÅ«ti replied:

When a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva upholds precepts, the three spheres are pure. First, one does not grasp that one can uphold precepts; second, one does not grasp that sentient beings are to be protected; third, one is not attached to precepts or the fruits of precepts. This is called the purity of the three spheres when a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva upholds precepts.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas take great compassion as the foremost, and the merit of the precepts they uphold is universally given to sentient beings, without obtaining anything from sentient beings. Although they universally dedicate it to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi together with all sentient beings, they do not see the slightest characteristic within it.
Because they uphold the precepts without grasping at anything, it is called the supramundane perfection of morality.
Why is this morality called supramundane?
Because it does not practice the same as the world, and because it can transcend and emerge from worldly dharmas, this is called the supramundane perfection of morality.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the mundane perfection of patience?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva cultivates patience while relying on something, thinking:
'I cultivate patience in order to benefit all sentient beings. I follow the Buddha's teachings and correctly cultivate supreme patience. I practice the perfection of patience.'
When they cultivate patience, they use skillful means based on attainment and together with all sentient beings dedicate it to supreme, perfect enlightenment.
They further think:
'I give this merit to all sentient beings, enabling them to attain happiness in this world and the next, and ultimately to realize nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.'
They cultivate patience while attached to the three wheels: first, the notion of self; second, the notion of others; third, the notion of patience.
Because they cultivate patience while attached to these three wheels, it is called the mundane perfection of patience.
Why is this patience called mundane?
Because it is practiced in common with the world, and does not transcend, move beyond, or emerge from worldly dharmas, it is called the mundane perfection of patience.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the supramundane perfection of patience?
SubhÅ«ti replied:

When a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva cultivates patience, the three spheres are pure: first, not grasping at oneself as the one who cultivates patience; second, not grasping at sentient beings as the objects of patience; third, not being attached to patience and the fruits of patience. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's cultivation of patience with the purity of the three spheres.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva takes great compassion as the foremost, and the merit of patience he cultivates is universally bestowed upon sentient beings. He does not obtain anything from sentient beings. Although he universally dedicates [this merit] to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi together with all sentient beings, he does not see even the slightest characteristic within it.
Because he cultivates patience without grasping at anything, it is called the supramundane perfection of patience.
Why is this patience called supramundane?
Because it does not share the same practices as the world, and because it is able to transcend, move beyond, and emerge from worldly dharmas, it is called the supramundane perfection of patience.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the mundane perfection of vigor?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, although diligently practicing vigor, still relies on something, thinking:
'I diligently practice vigor in order to benefit all sentient beings. I follow the Buddha's teachings and exhort my body and mind, never being lazy. I practice the perfection of vigor.
' When they practice vigor, using something to be attained as a skillful means, they share it with all sentient beings and dedicate it together towards unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.
They further think:
'I give this merit to all sentient beings, enabling them to attain happiness in this world and the next, and ultimately to realize nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
They diligently cultivate with the three wheels, namely, the notion of self, the notion of others, and the notion of diligence.
Because they cultivate diligence while attached to these three wheels, it is called the perfection of diligence in the mundane world.
Why is this diligence called mundane?
Because it is practiced in common with the world, and does not transcend, move beyond, or emerge from worldly dharmas, this is called the perfection of diligence in the mundane world.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the supramundane perfection of diligence?
SubhÅ«ti replied:

When a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva diligently cultivates, the three wheels are pure. First, not grasping that I can diligently cultivate; second, not grasping sentient beings to be benefited; third, not being attached to diligence and its fruits. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's diligent cultivation with the three wheels pure.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas take great compassion as the foremost, cultivate the merit of diligence, and universally bestow it upon sentient beings, yet they do not obtain anything from sentient beings. Although they equally dedicate it to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi together with all sentient beings, they do not see even the slightest characteristic within it.
Because they do not grasp at anything while diligently making energetic progress, it is called the supramundane perfection of diligence.
Why is this diligence called supramundane?
Because it does not proceed together with the world, because it can transcend and emerge from worldly dharmas, this is called the supramundane perfection of diligence.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the mundane perfection of meditative concentration?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate meditative concentration while relying on something, thinking:

'I cultivate concentration in order to benefit all sentient beings. I follow the Buddha's teachings and am able to correctly cultivate supreme meditative absorption. I practice the perfection of concentration.'
When they cultivate concentration, they use attainment as a skillful means, and together with all sentient beings, they dedicate it towards unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening.
They further think:
'I give this merit to all sentient beings, enabling them to attain happiness in this world and the next, and ultimately to realize nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
' They cultivate concentration while attached to the three wheels: first, the notion of self; second, the notion of others; third, the notion of concentration.
Because they cultivate concentration while attached to these three wheels, it is called the mundane perfection of concentration.
Why is this concentration called mundane?
Because it is practiced in common with the world, and does not transcend, move beyond, or emerge from worldly dharmas, it is called the mundane perfection of concentration.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is the supramundane perfection of concentration?
SubhÅ«ti replied:

When a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva cultivates concentration, the three spheres are pure. First, they do not grasp at themselves as able to cultivate concentration; second, they do not grasp at sentient beings as objects; third, they are not attached to concentration and its fruits. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's cultivation of concentration, where the three spheres are pure.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, with great compassion as the foremost, cultivates the merit of concentration and universally bestows it upon sentient beings. They do not obtain anything from sentient beings. Although they universally dedicate it to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi together with all sentient beings, they do not see the slightest characteristic within it.
Because they cultivate concentration without grasping at anything, it is called the supramundane perfection of concentration.
Why is this concentration called supramundane?
Because it does not share the same practices as the world, and because it is able to transcend and emerge from worldly dharmas, it is called the supramundane perfection of meditative absorption.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is mundane prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
SubhÅ«ti replied:
If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, although cultivating prajÃ±Ä, has something to rely on, thinking:

'I cultivate prajÃ±Ä in order to benefit all sentient beings. I follow the Buddha's teachings and am able to correctly practice the supreme prajÃ±Ä. I am able to repent of the evil I have done myself. I will never ridicule the evil I see in others. I am able to rejoice in the blessings others have cultivated. I am able to request the Buddha to turn the wonderful wheel of the Dharma. I will correctly discern according to what I hear. I practice the perfection of prajÃ±Ä.'
When they cultivate wisdom, they use something to be attained as a skillful means, and together with all sentient beings, they dedicate it towards supreme, perfect enlightenment.
They also think like this:
'I dedicate this merit to all sentient beings, enabling them to attain the bliss of this world and the next, and ultimately to realize nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.'
They cultivate prajÃ±Ä while attached to the three spheres: first, the notion of self; second, the notion of others; third, the notion of prajÃ±Ä.
Because they cultivate prajÃ±Ä while attached to these three spheres, it is called mundane prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Why is this prajÃ±Ä called mundane?
Because it is practiced in common with the world, and does not transcend, move beyond, or emerge from worldly dharmas. This is called mundane prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is supramundane prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
SubhÅ«ti replied:

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva cultivates prajÃ±Ä, the three spheres are pure: first, not grasping that one can cultivate wisdom; second, not grasping sentient beings as objects; third, not being attached to prajÃ±Ä and its fruits. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's cultivation of prajÃ±Ä, in which the three spheres are pure.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, with great compassion as the foremost, cultivates the merit of prajÃ±Ä and universally bestows it upon sentient beings, yet does not obtain anything from sentient beings. Although he universally dedicates it to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi together with all sentient beings, he does not see even the slightest characteristic within it.
Because he cultivates prajÃ±Ä without grasping anything at all, it is called the supramundane prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Why is this prajÃ±Ä called supramundane?
Because it does not proceed together with the mundane, and because it can transcend, move, and emerge from mundane dharmas, it is called the supramundane prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
ÅšÄriputra!
Thus, when bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the six perfections, they purify the path to enlightenment.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra asked SubhÅ«ti, saying:
What is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' path to enlightenment?
SubhÅ«ti replied, saying:
ÅšÄriputra!

Inner emptiness is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' path to enlightenment. Outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of the conditioned, emptiness of the unconditioned, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all dharmas, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of non-existence are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

Suchness is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment. The dharma realm, dharma nature, non-false nature, unchanging nature, equality nature, separation from birth nature, dharma determination, dharma abiding, reality limit, space realm, and inconceivable realm are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

The noble truth of suffering is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment. The noble truths of the accumulation of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

The perfection of generosity is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment. The perfections of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

The four concentrations are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment. The four immeasurables and the four formless concentrations are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

The eight liberations are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, the eight bases of overpowering, the nine sequential attainments, and the ten universal bases are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

The four establishments of mindfulness are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the eightfold noble path are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
The emptiness liberation gate is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, the signless and wishless liberation gates are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
The five eyes are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, the six supernatural powers are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

The ten powers of a buddha are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, great equanimity, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
The dharma of non-forgetfulness is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, and the nature of constant abandonment is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
All dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, and all samÄdhi gateways are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
Omniscience is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment, the cognition of the path, and the cognition of all aspects are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
Such immeasurable and boundless great accumulations of merit are called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's path to enlightenment.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra praised SubhÅ«ti, saying:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
It is truly as you have said.
By the power of which pÄramitÄ are such merits accomplished?
SubhÅ«ti said:
ÅšÄriputra!
Such merits are accomplished by the power of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is able to be the mother of all wholesome dharmas, because all the wholesome dharmas of Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and tathÄgatas arise from it.
ÅšÄriputra!
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is able to universally embrace all wholesome dharmas, because all the wholesome dharmas of Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and tathÄgatas abide in it.
ÅšÄriputra!

The buddhas of the past, by fully practicing the perfection of wisdom, have already realized supreme perfect enlightenment and turned the wheel of the sublime Dharma, liberating innumerable beings;ğŸ”½The buddhas of the future, by fully practicing the perfection of wisdom, will realize supreme perfect enlightenment and turn the wheel of the sublime Dharma, liberating innumerable beings;

The buddhas of the present in the worlds of the ten directions, by fully practicing the perfection of wisdom, are presently realizing supreme perfect enlightenment and turning the wheel of the sublime Dharma, liberating innumerable beings.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
